PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: O balanчo de umidade na regiуo Amazєnica durante o experimento BARCA
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: Um dos maiores problemas no estudo dos padrѕes de circulaчуo atmosfщrica sobre a Amщrica do Sul estс associado р escassez de dados observacionais sobre essa regiуo, em especial sobre a regiуo Amazєnica que domina grande parte do setor tropical da Amщrica do Sul. O uso combinado de observaчѕes e modelagem щ uma poderosa ferramenta para o entendimento desses padrѕes a nэvel global e mais precisamente sobre a regiуo de estudo, devido р escassez de dados. Diversos esforчos tъm sido feito para amenizar essa situaчуo, com a realizaчуo de diversos experimentos de campo. Dentre estes experimentos, um dos mais importantes щ o do LBA e o mais recente LBA/BARCA, um experimento multidisciplinar que vai envolver diversas Instituiчѕes nacionais e internacionais no objetivo comum de melhor entender o funcionamento biogeoquэmico da Amazєnia. O objetivo geral desta pesquisa щ a geraчуo de um conjunto de dados de re-anсlise de alta resoluчуo (20 km) para toda a regiуo da Amщrica do Sul utilizando todos os dados disponэveis durante o perэodo do experimento de campo LBA/BARCA e todos os dados da rede convencional e de satщlite no procedimento de assimilaчуo de dados, e tendo como objetivos especэficos a realizaчуo do balanчo de umidade para a regiуo Amazєnica, com e sem a inclusуo dos dados do LBA/BARCA no procedimento de assimilaчуo, e disponibilizar o conjunto de re-anсlise de alta resoluчуo para a comunidade cientifica em geral, em especial para a comunidade do LBA.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: No Grupo de Desenvolvimento em Assimilaчуo de Dados (GDAD) do Centro de Previsуo de Tempo e Estudos Climсticos do INPE (CPTEC/INPE) encontra-se em fase inicial o desenvolvimento de um sistema estatэstico de avaliaчуo de modelos de PNTC. Baseado em ferramentas livres e no desenvolvimento cooperativo dos usuсrios, este sistema recebeu a denominaчуo Sistema Comunitсrio de Avaliaчуo de Modelos numщricos de Previsуo de Tempo e Clima (SCAMTEC). A presente proposta tem como objetivo principal investigar mщtricas robustas para a adequada avaliaчуo de modelos de PNTC, que serуo implementadas neste software. Espera-se que com isso uma ferramenta para a avaliaчуo de modelos esteja р disposiчуo dos pesquisadores e profissionais da сrea de PNTC. Alщm disso, por se tratar de uma ferramenta de desenvolvimento comunitсrio, o objetivo deste projeto щ lanчar os alicerces da estrutura principal os quais permitirуo que contribuiчѕes da comunidade usuсria sejam absorvidas e que o resultado seja sua evoluчуo gradativa. ATUACAO-PROFISSIONAL.NOME-INSTITUICAO: National Aeronautics and Space Administration - Headquarters

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Data-Model Intercomparison Project for the Large Scale Biosphere-Atmosphere Experiment of the Amazon (LBA-DMIP)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: A fundamental question connecting terrestrial ecology and global climate change is the sensitivity of key terrestrial biomes of the globe to climatic variability and change. The Amazon region is such a key biome: it contains unparalleled biological diversity, a globally significant store of organic carbon, and it is a potent engine driving global cycles of water and energy. The importance of understanding how land surface dynamics of the Amazon region respond to climatic variability and change is widely appreciated, but despite significant recent advances, large gaps in our understanding remain. For example, aside from the increase in fires in the Amazon basin induced by El Niёo scale droughts, confident prediction of even the sign of intact forest carbon cycle responses to such droughts is not currently possible. We propose to address this fundamental question of sensitivity of the Amazon to climate variation with a detailed data and model intercomparison project. This project would leverage two key legacies of the LBA (the Large-Scale Biosphere-Atmosphere Experiment in Amazєnia) project funded in large part by NASA: a comprehensive dataset from an observational network of flux towers across the Amazon, and an ecosystem modeling community engaged in ongoing studies using a suite of different land surface and terrestrial ecosystem models to understand Amazon forest function. We will use this comprehensive dataset of meteorological data, carbon, energy and water fluxes from sites across the Amazon to drive and evaluate the performance of various land surface models whose simulations will be brought to this project by a broad community of collaborators who have agreed to participate in this project at no cost to this proposal beyond that of travel to the LBA-DMIP workshops. We propose to compare ecosystem model simulations of terrestrial energy, water and CO2 fluxes with long-term observations of these quantities over the Amazonia area to provide understanding on.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Integrating NASA Earth Sciences Research results into Decision Support Systems for Agriculture and Water Management in South America
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: We propose the use of NASA remote sensing and modeling products combined with surface observations at various scales to improve decisions support systems in agriculture, drought and water resources management for South America (SA). This proposal builds upon a partnership between NASA and various U.S. and international agencies and universities to contribute to the dissemination of NASA Earth Sciences research results within that continent. We will act to provide valuable information based on NASA Earth Sciences products to South American national agencies and other end-users, in particular for decision making that will lead to improvement of crop efficiency and water availability for consumption in South America. To this end, we are a partnership of institutions, both in South America [ the Center for Weather Forecast and Climate Studies division of the Brazilian National Institute for Space Research (CPTEC/INPE: Brazilian acronym), the Brazilian National Institute of Meteorology (INMET), the Brazilian Agency of Agricultural Research (EMBRAPA), Campinas State University (Unicamp) and University of Santa Maria (UFSM) among other local agencies ], and in the US [ the US Agency for International Development (USAID), Princeton University, and the University of Maryland (UMD) ]. . This proposal is in compliance and responds to the Paul Simon Water Act for the Poor legislation that requires special attention to be given to semi-arid regions such as Northeast Brazil, western Argentina and Atacama. Moreover, the improvement of crop yield per planted area will contribute to the decrease in the rate of expansion of cultivated areas in Brazil and Argentina in response to the rise of global food prices, demands for biofuels and food security. We will work towards the integration of remotely sensed products from NASA missions (e.g. MODIS, TRMM, AMSR-E, AIRS, CERES and GRACE), especially the multi-sensor (AIRS, CERES and MODIS) based continental Evapotran. Situaчуo: Em andamento; Natureza: Pesquisa.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: Evaluation and assimilation of NASA's remote sensing products in support of science activities in the La Plata Basin Continental Scale Experiment funding opportunity (NNH05ZDA001N-THP: Terrestrial Hydrology)
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: This proposal is a joint effort of the University of Maryland, NASA, and CPTEC (Brazil), whose goals are, first, to produce a dataset which integrates unique in-situ observations with sat- ellite data for the La Plata Basin (LPB), and then to apply the dataset in modeling and forecasting experiments in order to assess the resulting enhancement of prediction skill. La Plata Basin has recently been designated a Continental Scale Experiment (CSE) jointly by the GEWEX and CLIVAR Panels. Due to the unique nature of the region among CSEs, the La Plata Basin CSE has great potential for the calibration and validation of NASA remote sensing products, and in turn the region has much to gain from the use of these products. Many recent studies have identified land surface states as a key element in regional pre- dictability studies. Accurate depictions of land surface conditions and improved understanding of their interactions with weather and climate processes will be crucial for improving predictabil- ity in the region. Our overall hypothesis, to be investigated in this project, is that incorporating high quality observations of surface conditions from NASA satellites and other observing systems into nu- merical models of La Plata basin will improve predictability of the region's hydrology, weather and climate. The specific objectives and tasks are: Develop a multivariable dataset of in-situ observations that can be employed for satel- lite evaluation over the La Plata Basin. Validate remotely sensed satellite products with the in-situ observations. Assimilate and generate a dataset of land surface products that can be employed for predictability studies. Perform studies of the influence of land surface conditions on the predictability of the La Plata Basin. The relevance of this research is not only due to the yet unanswered scientific questions it will address, but also because it will result in a comprehensive dataset of validated sate.

PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO: The Impact of Land Cover and Land Use Changes on the Hydroclimate of the La Plata Basin
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.DESCRICAO-DO-PROJETO: La Plata Basin in southeastern South America is recognized as an area of great importance for the economic and social development of several countries. The scientific community of the region, aware of the sensitivity of this basin to potential changes, has developed a plan to assess the impacts of climate variability and climate change on the basin s extreme events, and to develop means to improve the prediction of seasonal floods and droughts. These activities are being developed in an international coordinated effort known by the name La Plata Basin Regional Hydroclimate Project (LPB). The project was reviewed by experts in hydrology and climate, and has gained the endorsement of CLIVAR and GEWEX, two Panels of the World Climate Research Programme that focus, respectively, on Climate and Hydrology. LPB offers a sound framework to identify the priorities in hydroclimate research and applications of the basin. A few Cooperative Research Network (CRN) projects funded by the Inter American Institute for Global Change Research (IAI) can be related to LPB activities; however, in those projects a clear climate component is missing. The current proposal will seek to complement existing IAI projects, and particularly the CRN-2031, to examine the impacts that changes in land cover have on the climate and extreme events of the basin. In this way, IAI will be able to have a broader scope of an issue that should be of high relevance to the agricultural progress of the region. Moreover, the IAI is uniquely positioned to contribute to the Outreach Activities and Capacity Building that are planned under the LPB project. This new proposal will focus on changes in land cover and land use and their impacts on the climate and hydrology of the La Plata basin, but will not examine the more general problem of gas emissions, anthropogenic climate change and future scenarios..
PROJETO-DE-PESQUISA.NOME-DO-PROJETO-INGLES: The Impact of Land Cover and Land Use Changes on the Hydroclimate of the La Plata Basin

South America Land-Atmosphere Coupling Strength

INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS.DESCRICAO-INFORMACOES-ADICIONAIS: This study examines the land-atmosphere coupling strength during summer over subregions of the South America based on simulations made with the Atmospheric Global Circulation Model (AGCM) of the INPE/CPTEC coupled with the simplified simple biosphere model (SsiB). The coupling strength is evaluated by the ability of subsurface soil wetness to affect locally the time series of precipitation. We follow the protocols of the Global Land-Atmosphere Coupling Experiment (GLACE) to measure the strenght of the land-atmosphere coupling. Over South America are found two main regions of strong coupling: 1) the La Plata Basin and 2) the Northeastern of Brazil. Some studies suggest that this regions are hotspot due to evapotranspiration recycling. Additional experiments, with different convective parameterization and with constrains in the surface soilmoisture, in which we isolate the AGCM as the principal source of the sensitivity of precipitation to land surface states were made
